topic.name: Biblical Stewardship & Economic Ethics
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Biblical Stewardship & Economic Ethics in History & Social Studies

objectives.objective_text: Identify sharing as kindness.
Name the widow who gave two coins.
Identify opportunities to give.
Identify fairness.
Name stealing and cheating as wrong.
Identify Usury (charging unfair interest).
Identify 'mine' and 'yours'.
Name stealing as taking what isn't yours.
Identify the story of Naboth's Vineyard.
Identify that money is a tool.
Name God as the owner of everything.
Identify the responsibility to use money well.
Identify work as good.
Name God as a worker (Creator).
Identify laziness as a sin.
Recall that God loves a cheerful giver.
Observe that giving makes us happy.
Recall that we should pay what we owe.
Observe that God cares about fair rules.
Recall 'Thou shalt not steal'.
Observe that we share because we want to, not because we have to.
Recall that we are managers (stewards).
Observe that money can't buy happiness.
Recall that Adam had a job in the garden.
Observe that we work for Jesus.
Summarize the concept of the Tithe.
Explain the difference between stingy and generous.
Explain the danger of hoarding.
Defend generosity as an antidote to materialism.
Summarize the command to use honest scales.
Explain why we should pay workers on time.
Explain the biblical view of debt.
Defend the rights of the laborer and the employer.
Summarize the 8th and 10th Commandments (Stealing/Coveting).
Explain that the Bible protects private property.
Explain the failure of Ananias and Sapphira (lying, not owning).
Defend the moral legitimacy of ownership.
Summarize the warning 'The love of money is a root of all kinds of evil'.
Explain that being rich is not a sin, but it is dangerous.
Explain the spiritual discipline of simplicity.
Defend the moral neutrality of money itself.
Summarize Colossians 3:23 (Work heartily as for the Lord).
Explain that all honest work pleases God.
Explain the dignity of manual labor.
Defend work as a pre-fall blessing, not a curse.
Compare biblical charity with government taxes.
Analyze Paul's instructions on giving in 2 Corinthians 8-9.
Interpret 'It is more blessed to give than to receive'.
Connect generosity to trust in God's provision.
Compare fair trade with exploitation.
Analyze the OT laws protecting the poor (Gleaning).
Interpret James 5 (warning to rich oppressors).
Connect justice to the treatment of the vulnerable.
Compare the early church sharing (voluntary) with Communism (forced).
Analyze the distinction between Acts 2/4 and Socialism.
Interpret the right to own property as a stewardship responsibility.
Connect property rights to liberty.
Compare Solomon's wealth with his emptiness.
Analyze the Parable of the Rich Fool.
Interpret Jesus' teaching on Mammon.
Connect wealth to the obligation to help others.
Compare working for money vs. working for glory.
Analyze the Protestant Work Ethic.
Interpret the Parable of the Talents.
Connect vocation to 'Calling'.
Evaluate the 'Prosperity Gospel' view of giving.
Evaluate the ethics of the free market.
Evaluate the history of collectivism.
Evaluate the spiritual risks of affluence.
Construct a personal plan for stewardship.
Synthesize the use of wealth for eternal purposes.
Construct a definition of biblical justice vs. social justice.
Synthesize economic liberty with moral responsibility.
Construct a defense of private property rights.
Synthesize the relationship between property and charity.
Construct a biblical view of wealth creation vs. wealth redistribution.
Synthesize the concept of 'blessed to be a blessing'.
Construct a theology of work.
Synthesize the redemption of work in the Kingdom.
Evaluate the modern idol of 'Career'.
